Killing Floor is a survival multiplayer game that utilizes: waves of enemies, poorly crafted innuendos, shockingly bad voice acting, and a myriad of conventional as well as unconventional weaponry. The sanguine lead revelry that takes place each wave is only made more demented and absurd by not only the appearance of the enemies, but the most dimwitted dialogue in the most grotesquely paramount scenarios. In short the periods in which you're not completely eviscerating the mutations known as specimens with the weapons you purchase between waves you'll be either disturbed and/or humored by the game's unique brand of voiced hilarity. Of course this humor quickly turns mundane after a few hours of play, but it will still leave you talking about dosh and how you should "grab it while it's hot". After certain facets of the game become stale you're often still beguiled by the sense of progression you receive while leveling up the various classes or "perks" the game gives you to choose from, and with the company of friends the experience is much more entertainingly refreshing as you blast through waves of specimens. These specimens come in various forms or types that all require certain strategies to terminate safetly, and so the game often requires teamwork depending on the set difficulty. Upon the end of all of these waves you are faced with a relatively challenging boss (once again depending on the difficulty) called a Patriarch which onsets the end of the map once defeated. It's quite painless to say that the waves leading up to Patriarch are far more enjoyable as most are dispensable slaughter fodder that satisfies the function of whatever weapon you choose. As I said before the weapon selection is quite varying, and your choice of device is often dependent on your selected perk. These weapons are purchased between waves some are cheap while others can be considered "pedestal" weapons that are afforded toward the latter part of each game due to accumulated cash. The varying weapons, difficulties, stock maps, player created maps, game variable changing mutators, and perk progression seem to keep this game afloat for some while others play each time a new update is released as the game is quite consistently receiving new content. The only notable con of this game is its propensity to become stale due to its repetitive nature, and while this seems inevitable for some all the gameplay leading up to such a state is well worth the purchase.

Finally decided to write a short recommendation for Killing Floor since I think this game well deserves it.

The objective on Killing Floor is simple: Waves of specimens. Buy weapons between waves, and kill the specimens during them. At the end, the Patriarch comes (sort-of a boss). Kill it too.

Of course, seen this way, the game in itself might not seem very attractive to some. And despite the few variations you see from one game to the other, excluding difficulty and number of waves on a game, it is quite addictive. The perks you choose (amongst 7) and how you need to play the game to upgrade said perks is what will always keep you playing. Because leveling takes quite a long time, you'll see yourself returning to this game numerous times. 

That said, the perk system can also be a turn-off for new players, given how higher levels on a perk get advantages (like resistance to damage). Still, with patience, it can be well rewarding and fun.

In all my years on the force, not once have I ever encountered a situation that could be comparable to Killing Floor. It's marketed as a Co-Op Survival Horror, but I'm unsure of what that really means because it sounds like some gimmick tossed around in an office with no real thought or meaning behind it. The story itself is pretty flat, Something you might expect from a direct-to-TV movie. You play the role of "Mr. Foster" who is tasked by some mysterious and unmentioned person to find and escort five random gentlemen across a barren landscape dotted with abominations, usually of the not-zombie variety. 

You'll eventually find yourself on the recieving end of a very angry horde, guided only by "The Traitor" who will often try to steal and sell from you, scampering off to different corners of the area as if by magic. The game has a laughably bad soundtrack, dotted here and there by random british gentlemen commenting on the events around you.

My god I love this game! It's quite simple : zombie massacre all over the place. But unlike some survival horrors, this one have a unique feeling that makes your adrenaline jump up to the roof. If you love to kill zombies, you love this game for sure.

It was a pretty nice kill-em-all zombieshooter back when it came out. After that they loaded it up with dozens and dozens of non-free DLC which, IMO, ruined all the power-balance and idea of that game. So nowadays I would not recommend it to anyone. You get more game for less money elsewhere - actually pretty much from anywhere. Based on how they treated this game I probably avoid it's sequel as well, no matter how they hype it.

This game is a very simplistic idea for a shooter game: No story and no levels/maps that you have to complete in a linear fashion. You and your teammates are free to go wherever you want in any of the maps while having to battle waves of enemies. With each wave being more difficult than the previous one. In between each wave, you go to a shop and buy/upgrade/refill your weapons and armor. At the end of all of the waves, you battle a big final boss and must beat him to win. Then you go to a new map and do it again. The game has 7 different classes that you can play as and switch between. Each with their own individual strengths. And as you continue to play the game, you will be able to level up the 7 classes and make them better. If you don't care about storylines and just want to shoot enemies and blow them up, then you'll probably like this game

You kill zombies or die trying. No stories to have to deal with. No missions or anything. Just pure co-op combat! A game played for the gameplay is a game you know is fun.

Sometimes I actually get freaked out in this game. Not  too badly. But things sneak up behind you like a beast in this game. You can be holding off waves of scary monsters in front of you while backing up and  suddenly you realize you're getting a a crowd of them grabbing you and biting you from behind. Getting surrounded in this game usually means death no matter how much life you have left. 

You have to stay on the move. Keeping eyes in the back of your head is key.

Some of the maps are stupid though. Some are so dark in attempt to be scary that you can't see what you're doing. Some are so confusing that you easily get lost and frustrated. Some are just simply too enclosed dto kill any large monsters befor ethey're too close to deal with anymore.

Still. Its good. I recommend it.

An addictive survival horror FPS. You and/or 5 others are forced to fight against several waves of AI zombie like beings. There are plenty of weapons to choose from ( such as pistols, rifles, shotguns, rockets, flamethrowers etc) which you can buy from the store, using the money earned from kills. There are also perks which benefit certain types of weaponry, which you can level up from meeting special requirements. You get plenty of steam achievements which vary in difficulty and add to the replayability of the game. Maps are varied from close quarters styled to open fields.

The main issue is the engine used by the game. The graphics feels a bit dated. Also, the AI may get stuck in areas forcing you to search for them in order to proceed to the next round. Team work while not essential is important in surviving the hordes, however its best to trust your own instincts in public games. 

Overall it is a decent survival game that should be played with others.

Killing Floor - кооперативный онлайновый шутер от первого лица про оживших мертвецов. Все действия разворачивается на одной карте с множеством развилок и проходов. Цель игры - нужно выжить, продержаться. Счет идет на число врагов. Для победы на любой из карт надо отбиться от десяти волн нежити, а затем прикончить «патриарха». Разнообразия режимов в игре нет. В перерывах между наступлениями врагов можно посетить оружейный магазинчик. В Killing Floor есть система «профессий» –  медик, снайпер, огнеметчик. Моя оценка 6,5/10.

Игра просто потрясающая. В ней заложен огромный философский смысл. Она заставляет задуматься зачем мы появились на этой планете, в чем наше предназначение и что нас ждет в будущем. После первого мёртвого патриарха мое сознание претерпело сильные метаморфозы, произошла переоценка всех моих приоритетов, теперь я способен видеть то чего раньше заметить ни как не мог. Всем советую поиграть этот, без преувеличения, шедевр!
Is an aboslute hoot as a single player challange and great fun with several people.

Magnificent Horror FPS that does not put as much fear into you as it should but hey whenever you are at Wave 8 blasting away everything that gets in your path, then you turn around to see that you have been backing up into a Horde of enemies you will begin to panic. KF sets the stage for what Steam is basically about. Good Games with not too high of a price, now given that this game itself goes on sale 4 times a year with the Seasons, it is a great first pick up. Your comp does not need to be the best, but for true excitement and pain being able to run KF on High is what you want. Mechanics are pretty on par with every other FPS. It was not hard to get the hang of but sure enough once you get it down you will be popping Zeds easily. There is not a story but then again who really needs one when you are constantly splitting Robo Santa during Christmas time at the price of 5 bucks.
